awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS+X:RES: Collaborative Research: Thermodynamic Phases and Configuration Space Topology
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this project is to use techniques developed within pure and applied topology to study unanswered questions relating to phase transitions. Phase transitions are unusual phenomena in the physical sciences; they are at once part of our everyday experience (e.g., the freezing of water) and yet continue to resist entirely satisfactory explanation. A phase is traditionally defined as a system throughout which all physical properties are effectively uniform. Certainly then, the transformation of water into steam should always involve a phase transition. Curiously, this is not the case; by constructing a path around the critical point in the pressure-temperature diagram of water, the liquid can be converted into the vapor without any discontinuous change in the density. How then can the definition of a phase be made more precise, and the presence or absence of a phase transition be understood? This project approaches the above question by considering a simplified system where molecules are spheres that interact by a hard sphere potential (i.e., do not overlap). Since this is often regarded as a prototype for simple fluids, this research could offer valuable insight into the factors governing solid-liquid phase transitions and glass transitions in other materials. Possible applications include prediction of the metallic alloy compositions most likely to form bulk metallic glasses, or a better understanding of the conditions leading to soil liquefaction during earthquakes.

More specifically, the project will study the statistical topology of the configuration space of the hard disk system. What is unique about this project is the emphasis on the use of topology for data exploration: functions on the configuration space govern the thermodynamic behavior, but the space itself is fantastically complicated and likely can only be adequately characterized with the help of computational and theoretical techniques that did not exist even a few years ago. First, the Reeb graph of the tautological function on the configuration space will be approximated using the mapper algorithm. The Reeb graph provides more information about the configuration space topology than the disconnectivity graphs common in the literature. Second, while configuration spaces of points have been studied for decades, giving the points positive radius presents new and interesting challenges for algebraic topologists. These challenges are expected to stimulate new developments in Morse theory.. Third, if the conjecture holds that a phase transition occurs where there is a non-analyticity in the diameter of the configuration space as measured by the diffusion distance, that would provide a dramatically different and more fundamental view of the nature of phase transitions in general. Any results pertaining specifically to the hard disk system will be tested for hard spheres in other domains to evaluate the generality of the conclusions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project intended to evaluate the possibility of explaining certain types of phase transitions like the freezing of water in a simple way; namely, the molecules have enough allowed motions to rearrange into many configurations when the system is a liquid, but are constrained to a small number of configurations when the system is a solid. More specifically, the purpose of this project was to make this explanation of freezing and melting (which is already widely accepted by the physics community) mathematically precise, a task that is considerably more difficult than it initially appears.

 

The standard approach involves specifying a number of molecules and the domain in which the molecules reside, then defining a space known as the configuration space such that a single point in the configuration space completely specifies the arrangement of all the particles in the system. The number of configurations available to the system can then be measured as the volume of the region that the system can reach in configuration space. For simplicity, the molecules were represented by hard disks and the domain was chosen to be a hexagon in two dimensions or a rhombic dodecahedron in three dimensions, each with periodic boundary conditions. The accessible region of configuration space was then evaluated while varying the fraction of the domain covered by the disks to test the hypothesis that the volume of the accessible region changes rapidly at the same packing fraction at which the transition from a solid to a fluid occurs.

 

A major achievement of the project was a set of techniques to construct explicit geometric models for configuration spaces of hard disk systems. This involved developing numerical algorithms to find the critical points where the geometry of the configuration space changes, to efficiently sample disk configurations close to the critical points, and to apply ideas from an branch of mathematics known as topological data analysis to construct a finite element mesh that estimates the geometry of the entire configuration space from the sampled configurations. These techniques were successfully applied to spaces as complex as that of the configuration space for six hard disks in three dimensions, allowing these spaces to be directly explored for perhaps the first time in the literature. Moreover, there was evidence suggesting that the time required for the system to fully explore the configuration space discontinuously increased during the melting transition, supporting the initial hypothesis. This part of the project directly resulted in three scientific publications and two publicly-available databases of critical points of hard disk and hard sphere systems.

 

The insights gained from the main investigation subsequently prompted efforts to develop a statistical thermodynamics for finite non-equilibrium systems. This resulted in one publication that provided explicit equations to evaluate extensive thermodynamic quantities in finite systems, and a possible resolution to the origins of microscopic entropy generation that does not appear to have been considered before. Other outcomes that developed over the course of the project include mathematical frameworks for quantifying local topological constraints on atomic motion in glasses (two publications), a description of local configurations of atoms around a central atom that is suitable for use in machine learning potentials (one publication), and several results relating to the construction and geometry of finite element meshes containing embedded objects of lower dimension (two publications).
